body:
Hi @sinceat, thank you for sibmitting my patch as a PR.

My response time is not so big as you mention since the question to me was submitted [about month ago](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-3046?focusedCommentId=15246649&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15246649) :)

Anyway it would be great to save original commit history.
In order to do this we need to apply original patch to the version that was used to create this patch against: https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/624781c1c4b89dce9f48fa80b841b5cd3d93aebb
After that result HEAD should be rebased against current master with minimal conflict (you have been resolving it on the patch level during submitting this PR) and populated with your additional commit. If you need any help with this, please let me know.
Hi @fduch, did the rebase. Would have done it that way from the start up but that's hard without parent commit id ;-)

@sinceat yeah, great that now its allowed for THRIFT to make PR's instead old-style JIRA-issues with patches submitted)

Now hoping this could be reviewed..

@nsuke I Make a issue, https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-3827
what to do next?  for completed pull request

1.thrift --gen cocoa idl.thrift
2.Add gen-cocoa file to myThriftApp.xcodeproj 
3.Add lib/cocoa/src file to myThriftApp.xcodeproj 
4.The idl.m file not found TApplicationException.h TObjective-C.h TProtocolException.h
@laozhp has this been merged yet?
@laozhp I incorporated this into a namespacing fix here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-3834
Looks nice, good work! Only a few things ... ;-)
I've filed issue to the haxe https://github.com/HaxeFoundation/haxe/issues/5264
@brianshannan-wf Can you close this PR?  I did not construct the commit message correctly for it to be closed automatically.

Just checking in here.. This request has been open for about two months with no response. 

Is the project still accepting patches? It doesn't look like anything has been merged in a few months, and the CI system appears unhealthy.

The project is still accepting patches, however as you can see we have over 100 pull requests (I have 3 in the queue) but we haven't been able to stabilize the apache build job for quite some time, leading to a backlog.  Only a few people have access to the apache build job and until we can get builds to pass the project lead decided (correctly, in my opinion) not to merge any more code.

Hi,

thanks! Could you just file a JIRA ticket according to our [contrib guidelines](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute)?
It seems that a `sock.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_KEEPALIVE, 1)` could solve most unhealthy connection problems ;)
lgtm
Just a few minor things, but looks good - thanks for adding this and updating the BASE64 encoder.
+1 thanks!
My approach is not very clean as it simply ignores node.js existance, it is meant to run only in the browser: https://github.com/endel/thrift/commit/32357443b5bfb5663ef3c45036c1680c08d04953

A job is failing due to `make[2]: write error` and it seems to be reproducible.
The same commit 4b7dbe3 as the current master worked for my travis account at the time of PR, though:
https://travis-ci.org/nsuke/thrift/builds/136239558

I suspect insufficient resource on GCE, so will try reducing concurrent threads or rebalancing workloads among jobs.
As steted in #1024 (THRIFT-3850) , it's a workaround against hypothetical resources starvation, by re-balancing workload between jobs.
This is a must-have for Swift support. Any eta on merging?
Is there a chance that the build failures get fixed soon? We are facing the same problem and this fix would be awesome if it works as mentioned!

We use this fix in our prod and it works as mentioned.

But as i can see the build is failed not because of my changes
So i am just waiting for review from commiters.

Please rebase your pull request against origin/master.  The build may not be 100% stabilized but we removed the offending Jenkins build that was constantly failing.  2 out of my 3 open pull requests passed Travis and AppVeyor once I did this. :)

I recommend you rebase this against origin/master because the list of commits above leads me to believe it wasn't on origin/master to begin with, and the fix should be small.  Plus this will re-run the build so it passes, and we can look at merging it in.
@jeking3 Thanks for catching it. It is rebased correctly now.
Is there a Apache Thrift Jira ticket for this?  The check-in comment does not refer to it.

Does anyone merge it?

I think I need this.
I'd recommend that you rebase your changes on the latest origin/master and push to make sure they are compatible with the development tip and pass all tests.
Is there an Apache Jira ticket for this issue?

This is for THRIFT-3823, you might want to change the pull request title.
As for the Appveyor build failure, that's documented in THRIFT-3826 (related; I just added a comment).
We can ignore the failed apache jenkins build - as such this one looks okay from a build perspective.  I would like someone with some go experience to code review it however.

I have merged changes from original thrift repo
But problems are still present
One  travis job is failed because of timeout
AppVeyor is not finished yet
Should i merge changes again?
I added the failure to THRIFT-3826 which documents our issues on the windows side pulling libraries from third party sites.  I'll see if I can submit a fix to work around this one, so hold on..
I tested the download of openssl which was failing last night, it looks like the external site is up again and responsive, so if you rebase and push it'll kick another build that should succeed.

@nsuke , what makes it be failed?
I could not find its cause.

So for Cocoapods/Carthage, you're also using Frameworks (startup time is negligible).  I'd almost recommend manually handling separate Podspec's to keep things Module scope namespaced, it doesn't seem right at this point to have Thrift generate Carthage/Cocoapods configurations.  SPM should be good enough when Swift 3.0 is stable to where it can point to specific files for modules, additionally Foundation is ready for server side use then as well so perhaps SPM is the way to go.

Either way I wouldn't recommend this as a 1st-class feature for Swift code generation from Thrift.  Perhaps as an option "Use Obj-C Cocoa Namespacing", so that its explicitly clear that this isn't a Swift convention, but an old Obj-C/Cocoa convention.

Proper Swift modules would be great. The Cocoa-style prefixes have worked well for us as a stop-gap solution, though.

I don't mind changing the option name or description if that would clarify things.

Yeah I think that would be the most appropriate way, making sure that people that use it /want/ to use it and/or know that its not a Swift convention.
SPM integration should come with Swift 3.0 support, which while in beta now is still not complete.  

Sidenote: If anyone's interested I'm working on building a Pure-Swift Thrift Library, basing it off of Swift 3.0 now (Started with Swift 2.0, but it was limited to Mac/iOS environments due to Foundation use, now Swift Foundation is part of Swift Standard Library 3.0 can be pushed for a public lib that works on Linux + Mac)  It's going to be in the works until Swift dev's finish up Foundation (still a bit incomplete as of writing this) but it will be much more "Swifty" (Following Swift 3.0 API Guidelines quite strictly), and may require an updated Code generator as well.  I'm not too familiar with the Code generators so should someone like to work with me for a Swift 3.0 Library + Code Generator that'd be great :D (Ideally i'm shooting to make it still compatible with the existing Swift generator, but should any changes be needed we should add a 3.0 generator option)

I have written unit tests for this change, but am not sure where to contribute them. I see no "cocoa" directory under the "test" directory. Is there another place where I can contribute my unit tests?

The diff generated by GitHub makes the change look a little bigger than it actually is. In TSocketServer.m, the `initWithSocket` method is effectively the same as the old `initWithPort` method, but with the socket creation code factored out into `createSocketWithPort`. Additional code has been added to create a socket using a path instead of a port.
:+1: makes sense
:+1: I don't really mind if you want to leave the two noted lines as-is.

Overall pretty neat. I still have a few complaints.
1. The document repeats a lot of stuff that can be found elsewhere, e.g. in the Thrift Whitepaper. There is nothing per se wrong with repeating stuff, but from my feeling it makes the spec a bit bloaty as it is now. We need to find the right balance here. 
2. I think the structure should be revised grossly. No need to panic, I'm going to explain what I have in mind. By looking at the bits and bytes the reader may miss an important point: The order of data is always the same and entitrely Independent from the wire format, because that's the way Thrift Protocols work. 
   - At the first level we have messages. They have a certain structure.
   - at the next level, a particular data item has a certain structure: a  map always consists of two types and a count, plus the elements. That does not change between protocols. What changes is the way how a particular protocol organizes the data onto the wire.
   - and one level deeper we are at what I mean by revising the structure: I would not constantly jump back and forth between protocols to explain structs, lists, sets, integers, etc. Instead, there should be one chapter focusing on binary, and another one for compact. That makes it much easier 
     a) for the reader who is usually interested in only one protocol at a time, and 
     b) for future maintainers to add more protocols, such as JSON.

Thanks @Jens-G . That's all useful feedback. Next week I have time to work on it further.

Regarding structure: it took me weeks to collect all this information and create the document. At some points I no longer could keep the entire thing in my head. Your structure proposal makes sense and clears it for me also :)
But `binary`is a basis type? Could yout try to explain the problem better?
What should I do with the failure checks

I need to know exactly type of variable. The current implementation does not allow it. I write serializer based on json generator's result and i can't serialize binary, becose i don't know how many bytes needs for variable.
@dtmuller thanks ! I'll look into the weekend after next.
Rebased now that the correct fix for THRIFT-3768 is in which was causing build failures... using this to prove that is resolved so I can re-mark THRIFT-3768 closed and THRIFT-3861 fixed.
Rebased on master to fix the TServerIntegrationTest hang.
Found that the automake environment wasn't building properly - will push a fix.
I only change php code, why the Travis CI build failed?
Waiting for master to rev so I can rebase and kick this build again.
Travic CI seemed to fail on something not related to my change. Can someone rerun the Travis CI build?

Bump.
Is anyone working on this?
Good catch!

In order to get this into the project we need an Apache Jira ticket to be opened against the THRIFT project and the pull request to ideally identify this ticket.  I agree with your assessment and your fix.  I would also recommend that as part of this fix we also attempt to re-enable the erlang compact protocol "make cross" tests which appear to be disabled:

jking@dvm-4:~/thrift/test$ grep 'erl' known_failures_Linux.json | grep compact
  "csharp-erl_compact_buffered-ip-ssl",
  "csharp-erl_compact_framed-ip-ssl",
  "erl-cpp_compact_buffered-ip",
  "erl-cpp_compact_buffered-ip-ssl",
  "erl-cpp_compact_framed-ip",
  "erl-cpp_compact_framed-ip-ssl",
  "erl-nodejs_compact_buffered-ip",
  "erl-rb_compact_buffered-ip",
  "erl-rb_compact_framed-ip",

Good catch!

What about other languages? Did you check all of them? 
=> If yes, what was the result? 
=> If not, why not? ;-) Could you do that?

Unfortunately, adding back in the cross language tests still causes failures :( Seems like there are other bugs lurking beyond the boolean one here

```
*** Following 9 failures were unexpected ***:
csharp-erl              compact      buffered-ip-ssl          failure(1)
csharp-erl              compact      framed-ip-ssl            failure(1)
erl-nodejs              compact      buffered-ip              failure(timeout)
erl-cpp                 compact      buffered-ip              failure(1)
erl-cpp                 compact      buffered-ip-ssl          failure(1)
erl-cpp                 compact      framed-ip                failure(1)
erl-cpp                 compact      framed-ip-ssl            failure(1)
erl-rb                  compact      buffered-ip              failure(1)
erl-rb                  compact      framed-ip                failure(1)
```
I didn't check out all the languages, just a handful to verify that the spec is: true = 1, false = 2
Some of the added files lack the ASF Header. Not sure about package.json, but phantom-js-client.test.js should have one.
It does seem like this could be refactored into a base implementation holding the common code and then an implementation per #ifdef branch that was introduced to clean it up.

Quite interesting, the job that failed is related to the code changes but the error message comes from boost about atomics, but the only version of boost I see with that file in it is 1.55 and it doesn't even have that exception, so I am still looking for where the error is coming from.

Looks like I have to use consume and release instead of acquire and relaxed when working with atomic load and store.

Unless you have extremely compelling profiling results, the only atomic memory order you should be using is memory_order_seq_cst.  Even better, you get seq_cst for free as the default parameter of load and store.
memory_order_consume is almost entirely broken in C++11 and 14.  Basically all compilers promote it to an acquire instead of a consume.
memory_order_relaxed is extremely difficult to reason about, and should be avoided.
I am okay letting things default to something else here.  I followed the boost examples and it passed the build with those settings.

This looks mostly good except for a few issues I commented.
The t_audit part seems to be the biggest challenge.
Not sure you're going to work through them, as some of them are from original code and others' newer patches.
Let me know if you have any plan on it.

Seeing the [commit log](https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/05b19b57cf2e224ab49e5cf983677361acb18311#diff-487498268b6e5a491d25456332fd44a1R107), it looks like more about not to use `acquire` for `store` and `release` for `load` (it's swapped).

@binaryseed thanks, I've verified your patch locally and it does fix the problem. It'll be merged soon.

I'm also working on extending cross language tests so that we can assert true/false and endianess which cannot be verified by current round trip tests.
@jeking3 can you rebase this one too ? It seems quite safe and I could just test it on my travis account but it's always better to have history here.
@matyapiro31 sorry for the delay, as the two "debian package" jobs for ubuntu and debian passed, I don't think we need any further action for CI.

@jeking3 thanks, merging as failures cannot possibly be related (go and dart).
Filed a [ticket](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-3883) for non-cross-test one.
Aren't we supposed to have a clean build before merging?  We found the erlang cross tests were still failing and it looks like you merged that in.

@jeking3 the atomics for TThreadPoolServer fields are for 64-bit field read-write on 32bit-x86 and other platforms ? If so, we only need relaxed.

That said, as @ben-craig suggested, leaviing it as default strict order (+without `load` and `store`) would even be better for readability.
Are you suggesting I get rid of the load and store calls and instead just use the provided "operator=" from the atomic?  I'm okay with that... it is much more readable.

The failures are from tentative re-activation submitted later as a separate commit.
I've excluded it from the merge.

Would I be able to tell that happened from any log or history that is public?  From here it looks like the tests were re-enabled because you merged the hash with them enabled (d150f8b).  I think it is important to have a clean and visible history so everyone knows what's going on.  If in effect you simply merged 49cefb9 by reverting the changes in d150f8b before pushing, that makes sense.
In my environment d150f8b41ef3a3f63fadcc595a99bc38628cd636 looks exactly same as 49cefb9563a18bc1cc7ac70ad0f1830019a3cd65 ...

The default op=, and even the default conversion operators from atomic<T> to T are fine.

@nsuke I would prefer we keep the access to TThreadPoolServer timeout variables as seq_cst.  The setter operations shouldn't ever be in performance critical code, and the 'get' side of things is happening in an already slow area.  On x86, the getters will still turn into regular 'mov' operations.  On ARM, there will be a couple of memory barriers generated, but those shouldn't be a huge deal.
@ben-craig are you saying additional code changes are needed?
Your latest revision look fine, I was mainly trying to address nsuke's post.

The latest build failure was environmental and passed all other tests:

```
make[3]: Leaving directory `/thrift/src/lib/lua'
make[3]: write error
make[2]: *** [check-recursive] Error 1
```
I fixed a few of your findings. On the remaining two issues concerning `t_audit/t_logging` and the shared boost test support I'm not sure what to do...
Was this set of changes tested with "make cross" as part of the build?
@RobberPhex could you rebase this against master and re-submit to get a build that passes CI tests?
@RobberPhex could you rebase this against master so we can get a build that passes all tests?
This needs to be rebased against master to get a good CI build, and needs a Thrift project Jira ticket.
This needs an Apache Jira ticket in the Thrift project, and needs to be rebased against master so that it gets a clean CI build.

Yes, continue to rebase against master and force push until it passes; if there are no changes to pick up add an extra blank line to the end of one of the files, commit, rebase/fixup and force push.  That will kick another build.  We do have builds passing now (not 100% - there are still environmental issues, but we're getting better).
This fix was declined per the thrift discussion due to security concerns.  Please decline this pull request.
